title: What are the best online web development courses? - Quora

response.answer_text: Learn Web Development for Free  Froggy – Froggy is a game where you help Froggy and friends by writing CSS code.Uideo – 490 talks for designers from 66 UX/UI conferences all over the world.Casestudy Club – Get acquainted with multiple theme researches dedicated to many product types. Study the investigations on UI, UX, branding and many other topics.Codesign – Visual feedback on everything.The Tiny Designer – Understand design and what it can do. (5-week email course).Design Lab – Learn design by doing, with hands-on projects & mentorship.Hack Design – Newsletter that teaches you design via 50 curated courses.Product Hunt – Discover and geek out about apps, games, podcasts, and books, every day.Design Research Technique – Huge repository of design techniques for every project stage.Angel – The place where the world meets startups.Beta List – Discover tomorrow’s startups, today. Get early access to the newest startups.Startupli – An app for testing your app ideas.Startups List – Collections of the best startups in different places.ErliBird – ErliBird provides quality real-world usability testing and beta testing with the community of 70,000+ global testers.Cofounders Lab – Largest community of entrepreneurs online.Founder2Be – Find a co-founder for your startup. Join tech co-founders, designers, marketers, developers, etc.Skillshare – Learn new creative skills. Join over 1 million students learning across thousands of online classes.Khan Academy – You can learn anything. For free. For everyone.Coursera – Free online classes from 80+ top Universities and organizations.Responsive Web Design – Free daily lessons to learn the basics of responsive design.Codecademy – Learn to code interactively, for free.Itunes – How to start a startup podcast.Startup Class – Everything they know about how to start a startup, for free, from some of the world experts.Startup Notes – Here are doodle notes of the most inspirational and actionable advice from each speaker.Closed Club – Know the reasons of startups failures.Design for Hackers – Free 12-week email course to teach design to hackers.Startup Talks – A collection of videos on startups activity.Rocketship – Learn from successful entrepreneurs each week about strategy, growth, and so much more.Udacity – Steps needed to build a successful startup.Mixergy – Learn from proven entrepreneurs.Hack Design – An easy to follow design course for people who do amazing things.Email1k – A free 30 day course to double your email list. Learn from experts who’ve grown email lists over 10 million subscribers.Design for Hackers – New (free) email course design pitfalls.Startup Digest – The personalized insider newsletter for all things startup around the world.Matter Mark – A hand-curated newsletter compiled daily to bring you first-person accounts of entrepreneurship, investment and other insightful reflections from the startup ecosystem.Pricing Course – A free, 9 lesson course that has helped 15,475+ freelancers learn how to charge more.Product Psychology – Get free lessons on user behavior.The UX Newsletter – Gather the information. Make sense of the information. Share the information. Discuss the information.UX Design Weekly – Join 12,000+ subscribers & get a hand picked list of the best user experience design links every week. Curated by Kenny Chen & published every Friday.Foundrs – Startup equity calculator – to get started.Qwilr – Ad spend calculator for healthy business: by Qwilr.How Much to Make an App – Easily calculate the cost of a mobile application using this handy tool.Pitcherific – Sharpen your message and become well-prepared for a pitch.Startup Equity – Figure out how much equity to grant new hires in seconds.Read more: 480+ Free Web Development Tools & Resources You’ll Love to Have at Hand

So first of all you should know that in order to do web development you're going to have to learn HTML, CSS, and some back-end language (most likely a web application framework like Ruby on Rails, Django, or Wordpress). That's because without the back-end, your application might look pretty but it won't actually do anything. I'm kind of controversial in my view that you should learn a web application framework first (and I personally believe that there are good reasons to start with Ruby on Rails 10 Reasons Beginners Should Learn Ruby on Rails). The reason for this is that it's important to start building something immediately in order to stay motivated to keep learning. The other answers here have listed a bunch of great resources. I'll tell you what worked for me: I started with the Ruby on Rails Essential training on Lynda (lynda.com Training | Ruby on Rails 4 Essential Training). It walks you through all the basics of creating your very first application – basically a simple blogging platform. You can probably finish it in about a week (there is 12 hours of video), and you'll feel a little overwhelmed. That's fine. Keep going and it will make more sense. Once you've finished the Lynda tutorial, I'd highly recommend the Ruby on Rails Tutorial by Michael Hartl – which is available as a 15-hour set of videos for $159 here (Ruby on Rails Tutorial) or as a free ebook here (Ruby on Rails Tutorial). The book is kind of dense, so I wouldn't recommend starting with it, but if you've finished the Lynda tutorial then it's a perfect next step. And a lot of the concepts should come back to you and be easier to remember the second time around. By the time you've finished the Hartl tutorial, you'll basically have built Twitter from scratch, which is pretty cool. From that point on, you've got a solid foundation of Ruby on Rails itself. I'd recommend checking out some Railscasts (Ruby on Rails Screencasts) for tips on building out additional functionality in Rails. Two other options for learning Ruby on Rails are CodeSchool (Learn by Doing - Code School) and Treehouse (Learn Web Design, Web Development, and More). I like Code School but I've never used Treehouse. Then you probably should learn some more basic Ruby and maybe some front-end skills. As far as basic Ruby goes, I'd recommend the following: Codecademy has a great Ruby track (Ruby). RubyMonk also has a set of fun, interactive Ruby tutorials (RubyMonk - Interactive ruby tutorials to learn Ruby). For learning HTML and CSS, I'd recommend General Assembly's Dash (Dash), which is probably my favorite front-end tutorial. Code School and Treehouse also have front-end tutorials but I've never tried them. At that point you should have a really solid foundation of development. Check out those resources and let me know if you have any questions!
